transcript.text: The world's population is predicted to
grow from 8 billion today to 9.7 billion
Population growth is linked with an
increase in greenhouse gas emissions to
which our planet is experiencing
worsening climate impacts now more than
ever at an unprecedented rate.
Surely there have been many climate
change solutions which have been
developed over the years with
sustainability in mind. But have you
ever wondered what your furry companion
could do about it?
Introducing insectbased pet food. Yep,
you heard me right. But why do we have
to consider this? Did you know that pets
consume an estimated of 20% of meat and
fish worldwide? The production of dry
kibble alone is produced on around 49
million hectares of agricultural land
each year, which is almost twice the
size of the United Kingdom.
Combined with the livestock breeding,
annual carbon dioxide emission is linked
to an estimate of 106 million tons.
Not to mention the large amounts of
resources required.
What's all the buzz about? So, the first
insect based pet food was introduced in
2015 in Europe as a novel and
sustainable protein source.
This concept of incorporating insects
into pet diets was inspired by the long
history of insects as part of the human
diet in some cultures. As opposed to
rearing larger body livestock, the size
of insects allow for less extensive land
use in the form of vertical farming in
which large scale breeding and
processing of insects such as the black
soldierfly larve, yellow meal worms, and
crickets can be done in limited spacing.
So what's the significance of this? The
estimated carbon dioxide emission 100
grams of meal worms can be up to 14
times less than chicken, pork and beef.
Not only that, the insects are fed on
organic waste from food or agricultural
byproducts which not only act as a waste
treatment but also produce bofuels and
fertilizers sourced from their pup√© and
excrements. You might be wondering is
this safe and can my pet actually eat
this? Well, insects are highly
nutritious and proteinpacked. In fact,
they do not differ from the nutritional
value of other meat sources such as
chicken, beef, pork, and fish.
A recent research found that black
soldierfly larae can be safely
incorporated into the diets of even
senior dogs. Moreover, consistent
feeding showed lowered cholesterol
levels in those dogs.
Secondly, insect proteins are naturally
hypoallergenic, which makes them
suitable for those with sensitive skin.
To top that off, insects are easily
digestible. In fact, nutrients such as
proteins and minerals were found to be
more digestible from insects than animal
proteins.
Although insects are highly promising as
a sustainable alternative in pet food,
further research in aspects such as
species quality, potential unknown
allergens or hazards, and also the shelf
life of insect products is necessary.
All of which still carry uncertainties
and act as obstacles to achieving
mainstream success in the market among
the global pet owner community.
All in all, sustainable alternatives
should be emphasized and their potential
not be overlooked. Most importantly,
enough awareness and acceptance from pet
owners is crucial so that they can act
sustainably and make informed decisions
in driving this market. I believe your
pets are going to larger this. Thanks
for watching.
